greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of integer partitions of n whose differences (with the last part taken to be 0) are distinct.
comment: The differences of a sequence are defined as if the sequence were increasing, so for example the differences of (6,3,1) (with the last part taken to be 0) are (-3,-2,-1).
The Heinz numbers of these partitions are given by A325367.
link: Fausto A. C. Cariboni, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..400
Gus Wiseman, Sequences counting and ranking integer partitions by the differences of their successive parts.
example: The a(1) = 1 through a(11) = 15 partitions (A = 10, B = 11):
For example, (6,3,1,1) has differences (-3,-2,0,-1), which are distinct, so (6,3,1,1) is counted under a(11).
results.author: _Gus Wiseman_, Apr 23 2019
